awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: Verification Mentoring Workshop at Computer Aided Verification 2019-2021
awd_abstract_narration:
This grant will enable students to attend the Verification Mentoring Workshop (VMW 2019) which will be co-located with the International Conference on Computer Aided Verification (CAV), to be held in New York City, July 23-26, 2019. CAV is one of the premier conferences in computer science, dedicated to the advancement of the theory and practice of computer-aided formal analysis methods for hardware and software systems. The purpose of Verification Mentoring Workshop is to provide mentoring and career advice to early-stage graduate students, to attract them to pursue research careers in the area of computer-aided verification. Funded students will benefit greatly from the opportunity to engage in the critical technical, professional, and social exchanges that both conferences foster.

Computer-aided verification covers a broad range of applications, from ensuring the correctness and safety of computer systems, to improving design and development productivity. The funded students will attend CAV, a top conference where they will learn about current research problems and interact with leaders in the field, and the VMW workshop which will focus on mentoring and career advice specific to early-stage graduate students who aim to pursue research careers in the area of computer-aided verification.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Attending a conference can be a transformative experience for a young researcher: it exposes them to cutting-edge topics and introduces them to leading members of the community. Hence, encouraging student attendance at conferences is critical for promoting the development of the next generation of researchers. In July 2019, the premier conference on computer aided verification (CAV) was held in New York City, NY. The goal of the Verification Mentoring Workshop (VMW) was to help encourage women, underrepresented minorities, and researchers with disabilities to become members of the verification research community. Building on the tremendous success of the first VMW held in 2016, we organized a workshop to nurture students who have already shown interest in verification research. This project provided financial support to bring students to VMW and CAV to learn about current problems and interact with leading researchers.

A specific objective of VMW was to bring women, under-represented minorities, and students with disabilities to CAV. To this end, the team publicized the workshop broadly, posting announcements on major email lists, web forums, and social media, and also by sending emails to researchers, encouraging their students to apply. In the end, VMW received 140 applications and selected 23 students for scholarships. The selection committee attempted to identify students who would benefit most from attending CAV and VMW, including students early in their career, those with a demonstrated interest in verification research, and members of under-represented groups.

12/23 of the selected students identified as women, other 2 as African American, and another one as hispainc. One student reported having a disability. This is, in general, a significantly higher representation than in the field at large, and female attendees remarked on the positive impact it had for them.

NSF was not the only source of funding, and not all students who received scholarships are based at US institutions. However, 20/23 of the selected students were funded through NSF and are based at US institutions. Of those students, 11 identified as women, other 2 as African American, and another one as hispainc. Thus NSF's contributions had a significant effect on the number of women attendees.

We received another 8 applications that were both eligible for NSF funding and identified as an underrepresented minority, but most of such applications were at too early stages in their career (e.g., freshman and sophomores) and would have not benefitted from VMW. We hope that these students will apply again for support later in their career.

The low number of applications from NSF-eligible students belonging to underrepresented minorities suggest that more work needs to be done in reaching out to students and inviting them to apply.

The workshop program consisted of presentations on mentoring topics (how to select a research problem, how to write a paper, how to manage a career, etc.) and technical topics (synthesis, verification, etc.). The goal was to provide students both with explicit mentoring advice and also give them some of the broader context needed to understand the papers presented at CAV.

The schedule for VMW, including speakers and presentation titles, can be found at http://i-cav.org/2019/mentoring/

We were delighted that so many leading members of the research community were happy to donate their time and effort. Only a few potential speakers declined our invitation to speak, mostly due to hard logistical conflicts.

The project was successful in its main goals: bringing undergraduate and graduate students to VMW and CAV; providing them with mentorship, career advice, and opportunities for networking; and targeting women, under-represented minorities, and students with disabilities.

Modified by: Loris D'antoni
